metadata.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
metadata.author: Shirley Jackson

knowledge_zone.heading: Imagery: Sensory grounding and vivid description

sections.content: Imagery is used throughout the text to sensory grounding and vivid description.

examples.quote: I am living on the moon
examples.scene: Merricat creating mental escape while enduring the children's taunts
examples.effect: Creates a vivid alternate reality that reveals Merricat's need to psychologically distance herself from traumatic social interactions

examples.quote: the grass was moving in the breeze and the cloud shadows passed back and forth
examples.scene: Merricat walking through the long field
examples.effect: Creates peaceful natural imagery that contrasts with underlying tension, filtered through Merricat's selective perception

examples.quote: finger of flame reach out to touch
examples.effect: Personifies the destructive force as organic and alive, filtering the destruction through Merricat's animistic perception of the world

pedagogy_zone.heading: From Device Spotting to Analysis
pedagogy_zone.intro_text: Most students can identify a device. Strong analysis shows what it DOES. Don't just label it—explain its function in creating meaning.

content.question: Ask yourself: Why does the author use Imagery HERE? What meaning does it create in this specific moment?
content.framework: Use TVODE: Technique → Verb → Observation → Device effect → Evaluation

pedagogy_zone.essay_application: In your essays, always connect device to meaning. Show HOW the technique creates the effect, don't just identify that it's there.
